The study of '''religion and video games''' is a subfield of [[Religion and the Internet|digital religion]], which the American scholar of communication, [[Heidi Campbell]], defines as "Religion that is constituted in new ways through digital media and cultures." (Campbell, 2012, p. 3).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Heidi|title=Digital Religion: Understanding Religious Practice in New Media Worlds|date=2012|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=978-0415676113|page=288}}</ref> Video games once struggled for legitimacy as a cultural product, today, however, they are both business and art.<ref>{{cite podcast | url= http://www.religiousstudiesproject.com/podcast/video-games-and-religious-studies/ | title= http://www.religiousstudiesproject.com/podcast/video-games-and-religious-studies/ | website= THE RELIGIOUS STUDIES PROJECT | publisher= | host=DAVID MCCONEGHY | date=February 14, 2016 | access-date= March 5, 2018 }}</ref> [[Video game]]s increasingly turn to [[religion]] not just as [[Ornament (art)|ornament]] but as core elements of their [[video game design]] and [[Play (activity)|play]].<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Campbell | first1 = Heidi | last2 = et all | author-link = Heidi Campbel | title = Why Religious Studies Should Pay Attention to Religion in Gaming | journal = Journal of the American Academy of Religion | pages = 1–24 | date = 2015 }}</ref> <ref>{{Citation | last1 = Grieve | first1 = Gregory Price | last2 = et all | author-link = Gregory Price | title = Current Key Perspectives in Video Gaming and Religion | journal = Gameviornments | issue = 3 | url = http://elib.suub.uni-bremen.de/edocs/00104918-1.pdf | date = 2015 }}</ref> <ref>{{Citation | last1 = Grieve | first1 = Gregory Price | author1-link = Gregory Price | last2 = Campbell | first2 = Heidi | author2-link = Heidi Campbell | title = Studying Religion in Digital Gaming. A Critical Review of an Emerging Field | journal = Online – Heidelberg Journal of Religions on the Internet | issue = 5.1 | url = http://heiup.uni-heidelberg.de/journals/index.php/religions/article/view/12183 | date = 2014 }}</ref> Games involve moral decision,<ref>{{cite book |last=Sicart |first=Miguel |date=2011 |title=The Ethics of Computer Games |url=https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/ethics-computer-games |location=Cambridge MA |publisher=MIT Press |page=272 |isbn=9780262516624 |author-link=Miguel Sicart }}</ref> rely on invented religions,<ref> {{cite book |last=Gregory |first=Rabia |editor-last1=Campbell |editor-first1=Heidi |editor-last2=Grieve |editor-first2=Grieve |title=Playing with Religion and Digital Games |publisher=Rou |date=2014 |pages=134–154 |chapter=Chapter 6: Citing The Medieval: Using Religion as World-Building Infrasturcuture in Fantasy |isbn=978--0-253-01253-1}} </ref> and allow users to create and experience virtual religious spaces.<ref>{{cite book |last=Wagner |first=Rachel |date=2012 |title=Godwired: Religion, Ritual and Virtual Reality |location=London |publisher=Routldge |author-link=Rachel Wagner }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Grieve |first=Gregory |date=2016 |title=Cyber Zen: Imagining Authentic Buddhist Identity, Community, and Practices in the Virtual World of Second Life |location=New York |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-0415628730 |author-link=Gregory Price Grieve }}</ref> As one of the newest forms of [[entertainment]], however, there is often [[Video game controversies|controversy]] and [[moral panic]] when video games engage religion,<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Reichmuth | first1 = Philip | last2 = Werning | first2 = Stefan | date = 2006 | title = Pixel Pashas, Digital Djinns | url = | journal = ISIM Review | volume = 18 | issue = 1 | pages = 46–47 | doi = | pmc = | pmid = | access-date = | name-list-format = vanc }}</ref> for instance, in [[Insomniac Games]]' use of the [[Manchester Cathedral]] in ''[[Resistance: Fall of Man]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Campbell |first1=Heidi | author1-link= Heidi Campbell|last2=Gregory |first2=Gregory Price|author2-link= Gregory Price Grieve|editor-last1=Campbell |editor-first1=Heidi|editor-last2=Grieve |editor-first2=Gregory PRice |title=Playing with Religion and Digital Games |publisher=Indiana University Press |date=2014 |pages=1–21 |chapter=Introduction: What Playing With Religion Offers Digital Games}}</ref> Concepts and elements of contemporary and ancient religions appear in video games in various ways: [[place of worship|places of worship]] are a part of the [[gameplay]] of [[real-time strategy]] games like ''[[Age of Empires]]''; narratively, games sometimes borrow themes from religious traditions like in ''[[Mass Effect 2]]''.
==Defining religion and religious elements==
[[Religion]] has several definitions. [[Organized religion|Religions]] that are [[Religious organization|organized]] can be seen as [[cultural system]]s, with corresponding [[religious behaviour|behavior]] and practice. They often have [[sacred text]]s and [[holy places]]. A [[religious experience]], however, does not necessarily have to be understood through an established religious framework.
Themes and questions about life and death, innocence and guilt and violence are [[Existentialism|existential]] in nature; while they are not immediately understood as "religious", they are about the [[meaning of life]].
==Use of religious elements==
[[Video game developer]]s use religious and spiritual themes to involve the player more deeply in the game.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Testa |first=Alessandro |date= |title= Religion(s) in Videogames Historical and Anthropological Observations |url=http://heiup.uni-heidelberg.de/journals/index.php/religions/issue/view/1449/showToc |journal= Online - Heidelberg Journal of Religions on the Internet |publisher= |volume= 05 |issue= Religion in Digital Games. Multiperspective and Interdisciplinary Approaches|pages= 249–276|doi= 10.11588/rel.2014.0.12170 |access-date=7 March 2016}}</ref> Video game developer [[Shigeru Miyamoto]], who used to play outside as a child, used his experiences and memories of exploring the forest and discovering a Buddhist temple in the design of his video games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2010/12/20/master-of-play |title= Master of Play |last1= Paumgarten |first1=Nick |date=2010-12-20 |website= [[The New Yorker]] |publisher= |access-date= 2016-03-07}}</ref> Canadian developer [[BioWare]] (''[[Mass Effect]]'', ''[[Dragon Age]]'') has in its offices several encyclopedias on religion, as well as the [[Book of the Dead]].<ref name="Bissell">{{cite book |last= Bissell |first= Tom|authorlink=Tom Bissell|date= 2010|title= [[Extra Lives: Why Video Games Matter]] |publisher= Pantheon Books|page=120 |isbn=978-0-307-37870-5}}</ref>
The negative portrayal of religions has been criticized.<ref name="Religion or lack thereof"/>
Religious elements are used in two ways: explicit and implicit. They are seen side-by-side in video games and do not exclude each other.<ref name="Understanding">{{cite book |last1=Clark |first1=Terry Ray |last2= Clanton | first2 = Dan W. |date= 2012 |title= Understanding Religion and Popular Culture: Theories, Themes, Products and Practices|publisher= [[Routledge]]|page= 130 |isbn= 9780415781060}}</ref> Religion in ''Mass Effect'', for instance, can be understood as an "[[unseen character]]".<ref name="auto">Irizarry, J.A. & Irizarry, I.T. The Lord is My Shepard: Confronting Religion in the Mass Effect Trilogy. In Heidbrink, S. en Knoll, T. (ed.) ''Religion in Digital Games. Multiperspective & Interdisciplinary Approaches.'' Volume 05 (2014)</ref>
===Explicit narrative references=== An explicit reference to a religious or spiritual concept is one that is clear to what it is referring.<ref name="Understanding"/> These can be based upon real-world religions, but also on fictional ones. Stories, [[Motif (narrative)|motifs]] and names of characters from [[religious text]]s are used as reference points.
====Ancient religions==== {{see also|Ancient Egyptian deities in popular culture}} Ancient religions and their deities are used in various ways. The religions portrayed are often no longer practiced, like [[ancient Greek religion]].<ref name="Religion or lack thereof"/> In the real-time strategy game ''[[Age of Mythology]]'' the player has to choose a "major god", which gives certain gameplay benefits.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-05-09-age-of-mythology-extended-edition-review |title=Age of Mythology: Extended Edition review |date=9 May 2014 |work=[[Eurogamer]] |publisher=Gamer Network}}</ref> In ''[[Prince of Persia (2008 video game)|Prince of Persia]]'' the nameless Prince has to fight [[Angra Mainyu|Ahriman]], an evil deity from [[Zoroastrianism]].<ref>{{cite web |author=Crecente, B. |year=2008 |title=Prince of Persia Ditches Roots, Gets a Final Fantasy Make-Over, |accessdate=18 September 2015|url= http://kotaku.com/5011425/prince-of-persia-ditches-roots-gets-a-final-fantasy-make-over}}</ref>
====Events and places==== Real world historical religions and events are used as inspiration for video games. For instance, while ''[[Assassin's Creed (video game)|Assassin's Creed]]'' (2007) is [[historical fiction|fictional]], it is set during the [[Third Crusade]] in the [[Holy Land]]; the player takes on the role of the [[Assassins|Assassin]] [[Altaïr Ibn-La'Ahad]] and is involved in the conflict between Catholic Christians, Orthodox Christians, Sunni Muslims and Shi'ite Muslims.<ref>{{cite web |author=LeJacq, Y. |year=2014 |title=Assassin's Creed Can Actually Teach You A Thing Or Two |url= http://kotaku.com/assassins-creed-can-actually-teach-you-a-thing-or-two-1576446550 |accessdate=2016-04-05}}</ref> While these religions appear, they are portrayed in a "sanitized manner".<ref name="Kotaku Good">{{cite web |url= http://kotaku.com/5509058/religion-in-games-less-a-leap-of-faith-more-a-suspension-of-belief |title= Religion in Games: Less a Leap of Faith, More a Suspension of Belief |last= Good |first= Owen |date= 2010-04-04 |website= [[Kotaku]] |publisher= |access-date= 2016-02-16}}</ref>
====Organizations==== Religion is often institutionalized, having a certain organisational structure. Most games in the ''[[Megami Tensei]]'' series involve a religion, or a cult.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://kotaku.com/5883361/the-rules-of-religion-and-why-the-next-one-just-might-be-a-game |title=The Rules of Religion, and Why The Next One Just Might Be a Game |first=Patricia |last=Hernandez |work=[[Kotaku]] |publisher=[[Gawker Media]]}}</ref>
====Religious violence==== In the action role-playing game ''[[The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim]]'' (2011) a civil war is about to erupt between the Empire and the Stormcloaks.<ref name="auto1">Thames, R. C. Religion as a Resource in Digital Games. In Heidbrink, S. en Knoll, T. (ed.) ''Religion in Digital Games. Multiperspective & Interdisciplinary Approaches.'' Volume 05 (2014)</ref> The Stormcloaks wish to worship Talos, a human ascended to godhood. The Empire suffered a defeat against the powerful Aldmeri Dominion, an alliance of Elves who have made the worship of Talos illegal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/what-happened-between-oblivion-skyrim-a-brief-history/2/ |title=What happened between Oblivion and Skyrim? Here's a brief history |first=Matt |last=Boyd |work=[[GamesRadar]]}}</ref> It is up to the player to help in the conflict.
===Implicit narrative references=== [[Image:Triforce.svg|thumb|right|175px|The [[Triforce]] from [[The Legend of Zelda|''The Legend of Zelda'' series]]. Based upon the concept of [[Mon (badge)|''mon'']], it is a recognizable symbol for the series]] The stories of [[action-adventure]] and [[Role-playing video games|role-playing]] games often involve world-saving quests. The player, as the protagonist, takes on the role of the hero.<ref>[[Jane McGonigal|McGonigal, J]] (2011). ''Reality is Broken: Why Games Make Us Better''. Maven Publishing, Amsterdam. Page 13</ref> The player character is often destined to save the world, which in itself is a [[prophecy]].<ref name="Religion or lack thereof">{{cite web| url= http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/video-game-religions-or-lack-thereof |title=Video Game Religions (or Lack Thereof) |first=Gil |last=Almogi |accessdate=2016-04-21 |date=2014-01-30}}</ref><ref>Slater, A. ''Prophecy, Pre-destination, and Free-from Gameplay The Nerevarine Prophecy in Bethesda's 'Morrowind'". In Heidbrink, S., Knoll, T. and Wysocki, J. (ed.) ''Religion in Digital Games Reloaded. Immersion into the Field''. Volume 07 (2015)</ref>
''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'' uses religious elements and motifs like the [[Triforce]].<ref name="auto1"/><ref>Cuddy, L. (ed.) The Legend of Zelda and Philosophy (2008). Open Court, Chicago. Page 196</ref>
==Video games as a religious medium==
Players and developers use games to express their existential and spiritual feelings. Video games as cultural objects can also provide religious and spiritual experiences, like ''[[Journey (2012 video game)|Journey]]'' (2012).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/community/2013/01/22/can-we-finally-begin-to-consider-video-games-experiences/|title=It's time we consider video games as ‘experiences,’ not mere products|work=[[VentureBeat]]}}</ref> Developer [[Jenova Chen]] said that "I feel that ''Journey'' is a very spiritual game. People from around the world ask me if the game has a religious connection. Many religions share an affinity with ''Journey''—this is because many religions partly share a common structure". Chen said ''Journey'' is based upon [[Joseph Campbell]]'s book on comparative mythology ''[[The Hero with a Thousand Faces]]'' and the [[Monomyth|"Hero's Journey"]] narrative structure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/religion-friendship-and-emotion-a-journey-post-mortem/1100-6367138/|title=Religion, friendship, and emotion: A Journey post-mortem|work=[[GameSpot]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/post/180290-journey-as-ritual/|title='Journey' As Ritual|work=[[PopMatters]]}}</ref>
After the death of [[Leonard Nimoy]], ''[[Star Trek Online]]'' added two statues in his honor,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/03/06/leonard-nimoy-memorials-added-to-star-trek-online?%20|title=Leonard Nimoy Memorials Added to Star Trek Online|first=Luke|last=Karmali|date=6 March 2015|work=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]}}</ref> and ''[[World of Warcraft]]'' added a [[non-player character]] (NPC) based upon [[Robin Williams]] after his death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/08/12/robin-williams-to-be-memorialized-in-wow|title=Robin Williams to Be Memorialized in WoW|first=David|last=Witmer|date=12 August 2014|work=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2014/08/apparent-robin-williams-model-found-in-world-of-warcraft/|title=Apparent Robin Williams Models Found In World Of Warcraft|first=Patricia|last=Hernandez|work=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]}}</ref> Developer [[Gearbox Software]] honored a late fan of ''[[Borderlands (video game)|Borderlands]]'', cancer victim Michael John Mamaril, by adding a NPC named after him in [[Borderlands 2|the sequel]]. Additionally, Gearbox posted a eulogy to Mamaril in the voice of the game character Claptrap.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.destructoid.com/gearbox-to-honor-late-fan-as-an-npc-in-borderlands-2-215160.phtml|title=Gearbox to honor late fan as an NPC in Borderlands 2|publisher=[[Destructoid]]|first=Tony|last=Ponce|date=November 4, 2011}}</ref> For their game ''[[MechWarrior Online]]'', developer [[Piranha Games]] sold a custom in-game unit called a Jenner, honoring the daughter of a player of the game. [[Canadian dollar|CAD]]122,210 was donated to the Canadian Cancer Society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/online-gamers-donate-122-210-in-memory-of-5-year-old-1.1302334|title=Online gamers donate $122,210 in memory of 5-year-old|date=23 August 2013|work=[[CBC.ca]]}}</ref> Losing his wife Pauline to ovarian cancer, ''[[Minecraft]]'' player "GasBandit" built a memorial for her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/games/5-Touching-Memorials-Video-Games-70528-p2.html|title=5 Touching Memorials In Video Games|work=Cinema Blend|publisher=Gateway Media}}</ref> When players of the online game ''[[Final Fantasy XIV]]'' heard that fellow gamer "Codex Vahla" was in the hospital on life support, they held a digital [[wake (ceremony)|wake]].<ref>Fahey, M. "FFXIV Community Holds Massive Vigil For A Dying Player" (2014), Retrieved 14 September 2015 on http://kotaku.com/ffxiv-community-holds-massive-vigil-for-a-dying-player-1673823454</ref>
===Religious video games=== {{see also|Christian video game|Islamic Fun}} Some religious groups use video games for education. An example is the Christian game ''[[Left Behind: Eternal Forces]]''. {{Clear}}
===Use of video games in a religious setting=== In May 2012, the [[Exeter Cathedral]] used ''[[Flower (video game)|Flower]]'' during its Sunday service.<ref>Narcisse, E. (2012) A PlayStation 3 Game Will Be Part of a Church Service This Sunday, Retrieved 15 september 2015 on http://kotaku.com/5909361/this-sunday-video-games-go-to-church</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2012/5/9/3010257/exeter-cathedral-flower-service|title=UK cathedral to use 'Flower' video game as part of upcoming service|first=Andrew|last=Webster|date=9 May 2012|work=[[The Verge]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]}}</ref>
==Controversies== {{See also|Video game controversy}} Opinions on video games differ from religion and denomination; there are religious groups that use games actively to convert people, while some games are [[List of banned video games|banned]] for religious reasons. Scholars of religious studies are also studying video games, by looking at the game and to the players and their experiences, with games like ''[[Journey (2012 video game)|Journey]]'' Religion is considered a serious real world topic, while video games are an art and entertainment.<ref name="Kotaku Good"/> As such, developers and publishers sometimes take precaution not to offend people's religious beliefs. Religious references in the Japanese role-playing video game series ''[[Final Fantasy]]'' were originally censored for the U.S. release of the games. It was after the franchise switched to Sony's [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] with ''[[Final Fantasy VII]]'' (1997) that the religious references were left largely intact.<ref>Ong, A. The Religions Behind Final Fantasy. History of Computer Game Design: Technology, Culture, and Business March 22, 2001</ref> Ubisoft's ''Assassin's Creed'' series show a disclaimer: {{blockquote| "Inspired by historical events and characters. This work of fiction was designed, developed and produced by a multicultural team of various religious faiths and beliefs."<ref name="Kotaku Good"/>{{efn|In ''[[Assassin's Creed: Syndicate]]'', the words "sexual orientations and gender identities" were added.}}}}
Despite efforts from some companies, there have been incidents with religious groups and video games. The German video game rating board [[Unterhaltungssoftware Selbstkontrolle|USK]] gave ''[[The Binding of Isaac (video game)|The Binding of Isaac]]'' a 16+ rating, considering it "[[Blasphemy|blasphemous]]".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/182380/postmortem_mcmillen_and_himsls_.php?print=1 |title=Postmortem: McMillen and Himsl's ''The Binding of Isaac'' |last=McMillen |first=Edmund |authorlink=Edmund McMillen |date=November 28, 2012 |accessdate=February 17, 2014}}</ref>
===Christianity=== The game ''[[BioShock Infinite]]'' is heavily based on the notion of [[American exceptionalism]] at the turn of the 19th century, and incorporates notions taken from Christianity to support the game's dystopian themes. One aspect of this was the use of [[baptism]]. One developer on [[Irrational Games]] staff expressed strong concern to the lead developer, [[Ken Levine (game developer)|Ken Levine]], that the game's presentation of baptism was highly controversial, leading Levine to with the developer to recast the baptism aspect as a notion of forgiveness rather than a religious tenet.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.officialplaystationmagazine.co.uk/2013/01/18/bioshock-infinite-altered-after-conversations-with-religious-people-on-the-team-says-levine/ | title = Bioshock Infinite altered after "conversations with religious people on the team" says Levine | first = Leon | last = Hurley | date = January 18, 2013 | accessdate = January 20, 2013 | work = [[PlayStation Official Magazine (UK)]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130122031459/http://www.officialplaystationmagazine.co.uk/2013/01/18/bioshock-infinite-altered-after-conversations-with-religious-people-on-the-team-says-levine/ | archivedate = January 22, 2013 | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/news/bioshock-infinites-religious-themes-led-dev-to-consider-quitting-6404620 | title = BioShock Infinite's religious themes led dev to consider quitting | first = Eddie | last = Makuch | date = February 28, 2013 | accessdate = February 28, 2013 | publisher = [[GameSpot]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/2013/03/01/bioshock-infinite-artist-almost-resigned-over-antagonists-religious-views/ | title = BioShock Infinite artist almost resigned over game's depiction of religion | last = Petitte | first = Omri | date = March 1, 2013 | work= [[PC Gamer]] | accessdate= March 2, 2013 }}</ref> At least one player objected to the final changes, prompting them to request a refund from [[Steam (software)|Steam]].<ref name="kotaku refund">{{Cite web | url = http://kotaku.com/some-dont-like-bioshocks-forced-baptism-enough-to-as-473178476 | title = Some Don't Like BioShock's Forced Baptism. Enough To Ask For A Refund | first = Patricia | last = Hernandez | date = April 16, 2013 | accessdate = April 16, 2013 | publisher = [[Kotaku]] }}</ref> The scene was otherwise well received by critics as less a commentary on Christianity but on as a representation of themes such as free will, evil, rebirth and redemption that were central to the game.<ref name="pcgamer baptism">{{Cite web | url = http://www.pcgamer.com/2013/04/04/bioshock-infinite-ending-explained/ | title = BioShock Infinite's ending explained, and what we think about it | first = | last = PC Gamer | date = April 5, 2013 | accessdate = December 27, 2013 | publisher = ''[[PC Gamer]]'' }}</ref><ref name="gameinform baptism">{{Cite web | url = http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2013/04/09/free-will-and-hope-in-bioshock-infinite.aspx | title = Free Will And Hope In BioShock Infinite | first = Matt | last = Miller | date = April 9, 2013 | accessdate = December 27, 2013 | publisher = ''[[Game Informer]]'' }}</ref><ref name="gamerevolution baptism">{{Cite web | url = http://www.gamerevolution.com/features/dies-died-will-die-an-analysis-of-bioshock-infinite | title = Dies, Died, Will Die: An Analysis of BioShock Infinite | first = Nicholas | last = Tan | date = April 9, 2013 | accessdate = December 27, 2013 | publisher = [[Game Revolution]] }}</ref><ref name="gamespot baptism">{{Cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/articles/bioshock-infinite-baptism-of-the-human-heart/1100-6407174/ | title = BioShock Infinite: Baptism of the Human Heart | first = | last = Gamespot Staff | date = April 21, 2013 | accessdate = December 27, 2013 | publisher = [[GameSpot]] }}</ref><ref name="relevant baptism">{{Cite web | url = http://www.relevantmagazine.com/culture/video-games/what-bioshock-infinite-gets-right | title = What 'Bioshock Infinite' Gets Right | first = Andrew | last = Barber | date = April 11, 2013 | accessdate = December 27, 2013 | publisher = ''[[Relevant (magazine)|Relevant]]'' }}</ref>
===Hinduism=== On October 22, 2008, Microsoft announced that ''[[Fallout 3]]'' would not be released in India on the [[Xbox 360]] platform.<ref name="Kotaku-India">{{cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/5067039/fallout-3-not-coming-to-india |title=Fallout 3 Not Coming To India |publisher=Kotaku |date=2008-10-22 |accessdate=2010-04-20 |first=Mike |last=Fahey}}</ref> Religious and cultural sentiments were cited as the reason.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/fallout-3-withheld-from-india |title=Fallout 3 withheld from India |publisher=Games Industry |accessdate=2009-12-01 |first=Jason |last=Lee |date=2008-10-22}}</ref> Although the specific reason was not revealed in public, it is possible that it is because the game contains two-headed mutated cows called Brahmin, or that [[Brahmin]] is also the name of an ancient, powerful hereditary caste of [[Hindu]] priests and religious scholars in India, or its similarity to the spelling of [[brahman (cattle)|brahman]], a type of cow that originated in India. Brahman, a breed of [[Zebu]], are revered by Hindus.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinemablend.com/games/Are-Brahmin-The-Reason-For-Fallout-3-s-Cancellation-in-India-12947.html |title=Are Brahmin The Reason For Fallout 3's Cancellation in India? |publisher=Gaming Blend |accessdate=2011-09-04 |date=2008-10-22 |first=Pete |last=Haas}}</ref>
The action game ''Hanuman: Boy Warrior'' was criticized by Rajan Zed, president of the Universal Society of Hinduism, for portraying the Hindu deity [[Hanuman]]. Developed and published in India by Aurona Technologies, the player controls Hanuman. "Controlling and manipulating Lord Hanuman with a joystick/button/keyboard/mouse [is] denigration", said Zed. "Lord Hanuman was not meant to be reduced to just a 'character' in a video game to solidify [a] company/product's base in the growing economy of India." He urged Sony, the publisher of the game, to pull the game. Sony's regional manager however said that ''Hanuman: Boy Warrior'' sold beyond their expectations.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/114224/Hindu_Statesman_Criticizes_Sonys_Hanuman_Boy_Warrior.php |title=Hindu Statesman Criticizes Sony's Hanuman: Boy Warrior |website=[[Gamasutra]] |accessdate=2016-02-16 |date=2009-04-20 |first=Leigh |last=Alexander}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://kotaku.com/5217826/indias-first-game-gets-indias-first-game-controversy |title=India's First Game Gets India's First Game Controversy |website=[[Kotaku]] |accessdate=2016-02-16 |date=2009-04-18 |first=Owen |last=Good}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gamepolitics.com/2009/04/17/hindus-protest-ps2-game-released-india/|title=Hindus Protest PS2 Game Released in India|work=GamePolitics|date=2009-04-17|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090420175535/http://www.gamepolitics.com/2009/04/17/hindus-protest-ps2-game-released-india|archivedate=2009-04-20}}</ref>
Zed was also critical of the use of [[Hindu deities]] in the [[Multiplayer online battle arena|MOBA]] game ''[[Smite (video game)|Smite]]''. In response, developer [[Hi-Rez Studios]] COO Todd Harris said that ''Smite'' would still be featuring Hindu deities, possibly adding more. GameSpot asked if characters based upon Abrahamic religions would be added as well, but Harris said that "the key Abrahimic figures—Adam, Noah, Moses, Jesus, Mohammed, are not that interesting in character design or gameplay".<ref>Connor Sheridan on June 29, 2012, http://www.gamespot.com/articles/deity-based-moba-smite-will-not-use-jewish-christian-islamic-figures/1100-6384974/</ref>
===Islam=== ''[[LittleBigPlanet (PlayStation 3)|LittleBigPlanet]]'' (2008) had a last-minute delay involving a licensed song in the game's soundtrack,<ref name=delay>{{cite web| url=http://threespeech.com/blog/2008/10/littlebigplanet-scees-official-statement/|title=LittleBigPlanet – SCEE's official statement|author=Three Speech|date=17 October 2008|accessdate=17 October 2008}}</ref> after a PlayStation Community member reported the lyrics to one of the licensed songs in the game included passages from the [[Qur'an]] and could therefore be offensive to [[Muslim]]s. However, no actual complaints regarding the music were made.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://community.eu.playstation.com/t5/LittleBigPlanet/very-urgent-about-little-big-planet-lbp/td-p/5627909 |date=16 October 2008 |author=yasser (solid08) |title=very urgent about little big planet lbp |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140601131006/http://community.eu.playstation.com/t5/LittleBigPlanet/very-urgent-about-little-big-planet-lbp/td-p/5627909 |archivedate=1 June 2014}}</ref> The song, entitled "Tapha Niang", was by [[Mali]]an artist [[Toumani Diabaté]], himself a devout Muslim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/technology/machinist/blog/2008/10/20/islam_sony| title = Sony recalls LittleBigPlanet over Quran quote in music | date = 20 October 2008 | accessdate=2 January 2010 | publisher=Machinist: Salon.com | first = Cyrus | last = Farivar}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/feb/21/worldmusic|title=The generation game – Music – The Guardian|date=21 February 2008|accessdate=20 October 2008|publisher=The Guardian | first = Robin | last = Denselow | location=London}}</ref> The game was patched twice, the day before its release for players who had received the game early, before its intended release date. The first update did not affect the song,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=265247| title = LBP 1.01 patch doesn't update song | first = Tom | last = Bramwell | date = 23 October 2008 | accessdate=23 October 2008 | publisher = Eurogamer}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2008/10/23/littlebigplanet-1-01-patch-adds-costumes-leaves-music | title = LittleBigPlanet 1.01 patch adds costumes, leaves music | first = Christopher | last = Grant | date = 23 October 2008 | accessdate =4 November 2008 | publisher = Joystiq}}</ref> whilst the second updated the game to remove the vocals from the track, leaving only an instrumental.<ref name="eurog_songsorted">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=265547 | title=LBP 1.02 patch sorts out dodgy song News | first = Tom | last = Bramwell | publisher = Eurogamer | accessdate =23 October 2008 | date = 23 October 2008 }}</ref> Some American Muslims responded to the recall and stated that they were offended by the restriction of freedom of speech. M. Zuhdi Jasser M.D., head of the American Islamic Forum for Democracy, was quoted as saying, "Muslims cannot benefit from freedom of expression and religion and then turn around and ask that anytime their sensibilities are offended that the freedom of others be restricted."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.next-gen.biz/features/muslim-group-condemns-lbp-%C3%ACcensorship%C3%AE |title=Muslim Group Condemns LBP "Censorship" |first=Kris |last=Graft |date=20 October 2008 |accessdate=23 November 2008 |publisher=Edge Online |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606001356/http://www.next-gen.biz/features/muslim-group-condemns-lbp-%C3%ACcensorship%C3%AE |archivedate=June 6, 2012 }}</ref>
The [[fighting game]] ''[[Injustice: Gods Among Us]]'' was temporarily banned in the [[United Arab Emirates]] and [[Kuwait]].<ref name=Ban>{{cite web|url=http://me.ign.com/en/news/10356/injustice-gods-among-us-banned-in-uae-kuwait|date=2013-04-29|accessdate=2013-05-08|last=Fakhruddin|first=Mufaddal|publisher=[[IGN|IGN Middle East]]|title=Injustice: Gods Among Us Banned in UAE, Kuwait}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/injustice-gods-among-us-video-game-not-available-in-uae|date=2013-04-30|accessdate=2013-05-08|last=Hanif|first=Nadeem|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|title='Injustice: Gods Among Us' video game not available in UAE}}</ref> Originally, the title of the game was rebranded as ''Injustice: The Mighty Among Us'' for promotional uses in those areas.<ref name=Ban/> It is speculated that ''Injustice'' was banned because of the inclusion of the word 'Gods' in the title, the cleavage exposed in the outfits of some female characters, and overall bloodiness.<ref name=Ban/> Eventually, the ban in the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait was lifted.<ref name=Ban/>
===Sikhism=== ''[[Hitman 2: Silent Assassin]]'' (2002) sparked controversy due to a level featuring the killing of [[Sikh]]s within a depiction of their most holy site, the [[Harmandir Sahib]], where hundreds of Sikhs [[1984 anti-Sikh riots|were massacred in 1984]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/sci_tech/newsid_2440000/2440713.stm |title=Young Sikhs force changes to Hitman 2 |publisher=[[CBBC]] |date=21 November 2002|accessdate=28 January 2008}}</ref> An altered version of ''Silent Assassin'' was eventually released with the related material removed from the game.
==Religion and violence== A study released by the University of Missouri stated that video games often emphasize the violent aspects of religion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5888663/study-says-video-games-have-problematized-view-of-religion|title=Study Says Video Games Have 'Problematized' View of Religion|first=Jason|last=Schreier|work=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]}}</ref> Researcher Greg Perreault said "It doesn't appear that game developers are trying to purposefully bash organized religion in these games, I believe they are only using religion to create stimulating plot points in their story lines".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munews.missouri.edu/news-releases/2012/0227-video-games-depict-religion-as-violent-problematized-mu-study-shows/|title=Video Games Depict Religion as Violent, Problematized, MU Study Shows|publisher=MU News Bureau}}</ref>
==Games as focus of religious studies== {{main|Game studies}}
For many years video games were seen as mere [[entertainment]], a form of "low culture".<ref>Mäyrä, F. An Introduction to Game Studies (2008). SAGE Publications. Page 30</ref> Playing video games was seen as a form of [[escapism]]<ref>Cuddy, L. (ed.) The Legend of Zelda and Philosophy (2008). Open Court, Chicago. Page 58</ref> and the medium was not regarded as a valid object of scientific research. To "play" games as a scholarly pursuit was thought of as "ludicrous".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://criticalreligion.org/2013/10/21/here-be-dragons-the-quest-for-academic-credibility/|title=Here Be Dragons: the quest for academic credibility|work=The Critical Religion Association}}</ref> It has only been in recent years that video games have become the object of scientific study.<ref>Newman, J. Videogames (2012). Routledge. Page 10</ref> Looking at the game as an object, researchers can explore religious and spiritual references. Video game research is done in two ways; the game can be studied as an [[object (philosophy)|object]], while [[actant|actor-focused]] research looks at the player.
===Game-immanent approach=== Video games, as products of human culture, can be seen and read as "[[Text (literary theory)|texts]]". They carry myths, stories and symbols of the time in which they were created.<ref name="auto2">Campbell, H. (ed.). Digital Religion: Understanding Religious Practice in New Media Worlds (2012). Rutledge. Page 145</ref> By "reading" video games, philosophers, sociologists and theologians have the opportunity to study the religious and spiritual themes in video games.<ref>Campbell, H. A. en Grieve, G. P. Studying Religion in Digital Gaming. A Critical Review of an Emerging Field. In Heidbrink, S. en Knoll, T. (ed.) Religion in Digital Games. Multiperspective & Interdisciplinary Approaches. Volume 05 (2014)</ref> This can be done in several ways.
*by studying the design, rules and mechanics or by talking to the developers *by watching others play (e.g. [[Let's Play (video gaming)|Let's Play videos]]) *by playing the game themselves<ref>[[Espen Aarseth]]</ref>
===Player-focused approach===
Video games are [[Interactivity|interactive]]; it requires input from the player to happen. While a video game developer designs the game, including its rules and story, it is up to the player to make the game "happen".<ref>{{cite book |editor-first=Luke |editor-last=Cuddy |title=The Legend of Zelda and Philosophy: I Link Therefore I Am |date=2008 |publisher=Open Court |location=Chicago |page=119}}</ref><ref name="auto2"/> As such, it is up to individual player to give [[Meaning (existential)|meaning]] to their experience.<ref>{{cite book |last=Newman |first=James |title=Videogames |date=2012 |publisher=Routledge |page=14}}</ref>
Video games allow the player to think, form and possibly change their own opinion about religious and spiritual matters.<ref name="auto"/> Players often discuss these elements on online platforms. For instance, some players made their own version of the player character [[Commander Shepard]] of the ''[[Mass Effect]]'' series an atheist, while others thought of him/her{{efn|Commander Shepard can be female or male.}} as a Christian.<ref>Knoll, T. "Are Those the Only Two Solutions?" In Heidbrink, S., Knoll, T. Wysocki, J. (ed.) Religion in Digital Games Reloaded. Immersion into the Field. Volume 07 (2015)</ref> As such, video games also give new meaning to the concept of religion.<ref name="auto1"/>

'''Religiosity''' is difficult to define, but different scholars have seen this concept as broadly about religious orientations and involvement. It includes experiential, ritualistic, ideological, intellectual, consequential, creedal, communal, doctrinal, moral, and cultural dimensions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Holdcroft|first1=Barbara|title=What is Religiosity?|journal=Catholic Education: A Journal of Inquiry and Practice|date=September 2006|volume=10|issue=1|pages=89–103}}</ref> Sociologists of religion have observed that the people's beliefs, sense of belonging, and behavior often are not congruent with an individual's actual religious beliefs since there is much diversity in how one can be religious or not.<ref name="chaves" /> Multiple problems exist in measuring religiosity. For instance, variables such as church attendance produce different results when different methods are used such as traditional surveys vs time use surveys.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rossi |first1=Maurizio |last2=Scappini |first2=Ettore |title=Church Attendance, Problems of Measurement, and Interpreting Indicators: A Study of Religious Practice in the United States, 1975-2010 |journal=Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion |date=June 2014 |volume=53 |issue=2 |page=249–267 |doi=10.1111/jssr.12115 |url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/jssr.12115 |publisher=Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion |issn=0021-8294}}</ref>
==Diversity in an individuals' beliefs, affiliations, and behaviors==
Decades of anthropological, sociological, and psychological research have established that "religious congruence" (the assumption that religious beliefs and values are tightly integrated in an individual's mind or that religious practices and behaviors follow directly from religious beliefs or that religious beliefs are chronologically linear and stable across different contexts) is actually rare. People’s religious ideas are fragmented, loosely connected, and context-dependent; like in all other domains of culture and in life. The beliefs, affiliations, and behaviors of any individual are complex activities that have many sources including culture. As examples of religious incongruence he notes, "Observant Jews may not believe what they say in their Sabbath prayers. Christian ministers may not believe in God. And people who regularly dance for rain don’t do it in the dry season."<ref name="chaves">{{cite journal|last1=Chaves|first1=Mark|title=SSSR Presidential Address Rain Dances in the Dry Season: Overcoming the Religious Congruence Fallacy|journal=Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion|date=March 2010|volume=49|issue=1|pages=1–14|doi=10.1111/j.1468-5906.2009.01489.x}}</ref>
Demographic studies often show wide diversity of religious beliefs, belonging, and practices in both religious and non-religious populations. For instance, out of Americans who are not religious and not seeking religion: 68% believe in God, 12% are atheists, 17% are agnostics; also, in terms of self-identification of religiosity 18% consider themselves religious, 37% consider themselves as spiritual but not religious, and 42% considers themselves as neither spiritual nor religious; and 21% pray every day and 24% pray once a month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commons.trincoll.edu/aris/files/2011/08/NONES_08.pdf|title=American Nones: The Profile of the No Religion Population|year=2008|publisher=American Religious Identification Survey|accessdate=2014-01-30}}</ref><ref name="Pew 2012 breakdown">{{cite web |url=http://www.pewforum.org/2012/10/09/nones-on-the-rise-religion/ |title=Religion and the Unaffiliated |work="Nones" on the Rise |date=October 9, 2012 |publisher=[[Pew Research Center]]: Religion & Public Life |accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="Most Nones Believe God">{{cite web|title=Most of the Religiously Unaffiliated Still Keep Belief in God|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/daily-number/most-of-the-religiously-unaffiliated-still-keep-belief-in-god/|website=Pew Research Center|date=November 15, 2012}}</ref> Global studies on religion also show diversity.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Global Religious Landscape|url=http://www.pewforum.org/2012/12/18/global-religious-landscape-exec/|website=Pew Research Center}}</ref>
[[File:Importance of Religion in the World (Gallup Poll 2008-2009).svg|thumb|550px|Results of a 2008/2009 Gallup poll on whether respondents said that religion was "important in [their] daily life."<ref name=gallup-religiosity-poor-nations>{{cite web|last1=Crabtree|first1=Steve|title=Religiosity Highest in World's Poorest Nations|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/142727/religiosity-highest-world-poorest-nations.aspx|publisher=Gallup|accessdate=27 May 2015}} (in which numbers have been rounded)</ref><ref name="Gallup2">[https://worldview.gallup.com/default.aspx GALLUP WorldView] - data accessed on 17 january 2009</ref> {| border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width:100%; background:none;" |- |valign="top"| {{legend|#002255|90%-100%}} {{legend|#0044aa|80%-89%}} {{legend|#0055d4|70%-79%}} {{legend|#0066ff|60%-69%}} | valign=top | {{legend|#2a7fff|50%-59%}} {{legend|#5599ff|40%-49%}} {{legend|#80b3ff|30%-39%}} {{legend|#aaccff|20%-29%}} | valign=top | {{legend|#d5e5ff|10%-19%}} {{legend|white|0%-9%}} {{legend|#c0c0c0ff|No data}} |}]]
==Components== Numerous studies have explored the different components of human religiosity (Brink, 1993; Hill & Hood 1999). What most have found is that there are multiple dimensions (they often employ [[factor analysis]]). For instance, Cornwall, Albrecht, Cunningham and Pitcher (1986) identify six dimensions of religiosity based on the understanding that there are at least three components to religious behavior: knowing (cognition in the mind), feeling (effect to the spirit), and doing (behavior of the body). For each of these components of religiosity, there were two cross classifications resulting in the six dimensions:<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cornwall |author2=Albrecht |author3=Cunningham |author4=Pitcher |title=The Dimensions of Religiosity: A Conceptual Model with an Empirical Test|journal=Review of Religious Research|year=1986|volume=27|issue=3|pages=226–244|doi=10.2307/3511418}}</ref> *Cognition **traditional [[orthodoxy]] **particularistic orthodoxy *Effect **Palpable **Tangible *Behavior **religious behavior **religious participation
Other researchers have found different dimensions, ranging generally from four to twelve components. What most measures of religiosity find is that there is at least some distinction between religious doctrine, religious practice, and [[spirituality]].
For example{{original research inline|date=February 2011}}, one can accept the truthfulness of the [[Bible]] (belief dimension), but never attend a church or even belong to an organized religion (practice dimension). Another example is an individual who does not hold orthodox [[Christian]] doctrines (belief dimension), but does attend a [[Charismatic Movement|charismatic]] [[worship]] service (practice dimension) in order to develop his/her sense of oneness with the [[divinity|divine]] (spirituality dimension).
An individual could disavow all doctrines associated with organized religions (belief dimension), not affiliate with an organized religion or attend religious services (practice dimension), and at the same time be strongly committed to a higher power and feel that the connection with that higher power is ultimately relevant (spirituality dimension). These are explanatory examples of the broadest dimensions of religiosity and may not be reflected in specific religiosity measures.
Most dimensions of religiosity are correlated, meaning people who often attend church services (practice dimension) are also likely to score highly on the belief and spirituality dimensions. But individuals do not have to score high on all dimensions or low on all dimensions; their scores can vary by dimension.
[[Sociologists]] have differed over the exact number of components of religiosity. [[Charles Y. Glock|Charles Glock]]'s five-dimensional approach (Glock, 1972: 39) was among the first of its kind in the field of [[sociology of religion]].<ref>Glock, C. Y. (1972) ‘On the Study of Religious Commitment’ in J. E. Faulkner (ed.) Religion’s Influence in Contemporary Society, Readings in the Sociology of Religion, Ohio: Charles E. Merril: 38-56.</ref> Other sociologists adapted Glock's list to include additional components (see for example, a [[Mervin F. Verbit#The Twenty Four-Dimensional Religiosity Measure|six component measure]] by [[Mervin F. Verbit]]).<ref>Verbit, M. F. (1970). The components and dimensions of religious behavior: Toward a reconceptualization of religiosity. American mosaic, 24, 39.</ref><ref>Küçükcan, T. (2010). Multidimensional Approach to Religion: a way of looking at religious phenomena. Journal for the Study of Religions and Ideologies, 4(10), 60-70.</ref><ref>http://www.eskieserler.com/dosyalar/mpdf%20(1135).pdf</ref>
== Contributions ==
===Genes and environment===
[[File:Church Attendance and Welfare Spending Graph.png|thumb|350px|National welfare spending vs church attendance in Christian societies<ref>{{cite journal | title = State Welfare Spending and Religiosity | journal = Comparative Political Studies | first = Anthony | last = Gill |author2=Erik Lundsgaarde | volume = 16 | issue = 4 | pages = 399–436 | year = 2004| doi = 10.1177/1043463104046694 }} [http://faculty.washington.edu/tgill/Gill%20Lundsgaarde%20Welfare%20Religion.pdf Free PDF]</ref>]]
The contributions of [[genes]] and [[Natural environment|environment]] to religiosity have been quantified in [[twin study|studies of twins]] (Bouchard ''et al.'', 1999; Kirk ''et al.'', 1999) and sociological studies of welfare, availability, and legal regulations <ref>Nolan, P., & Lenski, G. E. (2010). Human societies: Introduction to macrosociology. Boulder, CO: Paradigm Publisher.</ref> ([[state religions]], etc.).
Koenig ''et al.'' (2005) report that the contribution of genes to variation in religiosity (called [[heritability]]) increases from 12% to 44% and the contribution of shared (family) effects decreases from 56% to 18% between [[adolescence]] and [[adulthood]].<ref>L. B. Koenig, M. McGue, R. F. Krueger and T. J. Bouchard, Jr. (2005). Genetic and environmental influences on religiousness: findings for retrospective and current religiousness ratings. ''Journal of Personality'', '''73''', [https://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-6494.2005.00316.x 471-88]</ref>
A market-based theory of religious choice and governmental regulation of religion have been the dominant theories used to explain variations of religiosity between societies{{Clarify|date=January 2017}}. However, Gill and Lundsgaarde (2004) <ref>{{cite journal | title = State Welfare Spending and Religiosity | journal = Comparative Political Studies | first = Anthony | last = Gill |author2=Erik Lundsgaarde | volume = 16 | issue = 4 | pages = 399–436 | year = 2004| doi = 10.1177/1043463104046694 }} [http://faculty.washington.edu/tgill/Gill%20Lundsgaarde%20Welfare%20Religion.pdf Free PDF]</ref> documented a much stronger correlation between welfare state spending and religiosity. See "Welfare spending vs Church attendance" diagram on the right.
===Just-world hypothesis=== Studies have found [[Just-world hypothesis|belief in a just world]] to be correlated with aspects of religiousness.<ref>Begue, L. (2002). Beliefs in justice and faith in people: just world, religiosity and interpersonal trust. ''Personality and Individual Differences'', 32(3), 375-382.</ref><ref>Kurst, J., Bjorck, J., & Tan, S. (2000). Causal attributions for uncontrollable negative events. ''Journal of Psychology and Christianity'', 19, 47–60.</ref>
===Risk-aversion=== Several studies have discovered a positive correlation between the degree of religiousness and [[Risk aversion]]<ref>{{cite journal | title = Risk aversion and religion | journal = Journal of Risk and Uncertainty | first = Charles | last = Noussair |author2=Stefan T. Trautmann|author3=Gijs van de Kuilen|author4=Nathanael Vellekoop | volume = 47| issue = 2 | pages = 165–183 | year = 2013| doi = 10.1007/s11166-013-9174-8}}.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title = Does local religiosity matter for bank risk-taking? | journal = Journal of Corporate Finance | first = Binay| last = Adhikari|author2=Anup Agrawal| volume = 38|pages = 272–293| year = 2016| doi = 10.1016/j.jcorpfin.2016.01.009}}.</ref>

A '''religious delusion''' is any [[delusion]] involving religious themes or subject matter.<ref name="Sims">{{cite document|title=Moses and Monotheism|last=Freud | first= Sigmund | authorlink = Sigmund Freud | year=1939 | url=https://archive.org/details/mosesandmonothei032233mbp}} cited in: {{cite document | title = Is Faith delusion? | last=Sims | first = A. | publisher=[[Royal College of Psychiatrists]] | url=http://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/pdf/is%20faith%20delusion%20andrew%20sims%20editedx.pdf}}{{Verify source|what is this actually citing?|date=February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/0010-440X(90)90023-L |title=On defining delusions |year=1990 |last1=Spitzer |first1=Manfred |journal=Comprehensive Psychiatry |volume=31 |issue=5 |pages=377–97 |pmid=2225797}}</ref> Though a small minority of psychologists have characterized all or nearly all religion as delusion,<ref name="Sims"/><ref>{{cite journal |first1=Ryan |last1=McKay |year=2004 |title=Hallucinating God? The Cognitive Neuropsychiatry of Religious Belief and Experience |journal=Evolution and Cognition |volume=10 |issue=1 |pages=114–25 |url=http://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid:d6409506-5f22-4b82-bcc4-64f7cf5ad8f6}}</ref> others focus solely on a denial of any spiritual cause of symptoms exhibited by a patient and look for other answers relating to a chemical imbalance in the brain.
==Definition == Individuals experiencing religious delusions are preoccupied with religious subjects that are not within the expected beliefs for an individual's background, including culture, education, and known experiences of religion. These preoccupations are incongruous with the [[mood (psychology)|mood]] of the subject. Falling within the definition also are delusions arising in [[psychotic depression]]; however, these must present within a [[major depressive episode]] and be congruous with mood.<ref>{{cite book | last1=Lieberman | first1=Jeffrey A. | last2=Stroup | first2 = T. Scott | last3=Perkins | first3 = Diana O. | title=The American Psychiatric Publishing Textbook of Schizophrenia | year=2006 | publisher=American Psychiatric Publishing | isbn=9781585626465 | page=199}}</ref>
Researchers in a 2000 study found religious delusions to be unrelated to any specific set of diagnostic criteria, but correlated with demographic criteria, primarily age.<ref name="raja2000">{{cite journal |first1=M. |last1=Raja |first2=A. |last2=Azzoni |first3=L. |last3=Lubich |year=2000 |title=Religious delusion: An observational study of religious delusion in a population of 313 acute psychiatric inpatients |journal=Schweizer Archiv für Neurologie und Psychiatrie |volume=151 |issue=1 |pages=22–9 |url=http://www.sanp.ch/pdf/2000/2000-01/2000-01-058.PDF | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322210939/http://www.sanp.ch/pdf/2000/2000-01/2000-01-058.PDF | archivedate=2012-03-22}}</ref> In a comparative study sampling 313 patients, those with religious delusion were found to be aged older, and had been placed on a drug regime or started a treatment programme at an earlier stage. In the context of [[Medical sign|presentation]], their [[Global Assessment of Functioning|global functioning]] was found to be worse than another group of patients without religious delusions. The first group also scored higher on the [[Scale for the Assessment of Positive Symptoms]] (SAPS),<ref>{{cite document | publisher=Psychiatric [[University Hospital Zurich]] | last=Andreasen | first = Nancy C. | year=2007 |url=http://www.bli.uzh.ch/PDF/saps.pdf |title=SCALE FOR THE ASSESSMENT OF POSITIVE SYMPTOMS | accessdate=2012-01-30}}</ref> had a greater total on the [[Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale]] (BPRS),<ref>{{cite document | publisher=[[The University of Iowa]] | work = Iowa Coalition on Mental Health and Aging | url=http://www.public-health.uiowa.edu/icmha/outreach/documents/BPRS_expanded.PDF | title=Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS) | accessdate=2012-01-30}}</ref> and were treated with a higher mean number of [[neuroleptic]] medications of differing types during their hospitalization.<ref name="raja2000"/>
Religious delusion was found in 2007 to strongly correlate with "temporolimbic overactivity".<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/10398560601083118 |title=The Interface Between Religion and Psychosis |year=2007 |last1=Ng |first1=Felicity |author10=The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists |journal=Australasian Psychiatry |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=62–66 | pmid = 17464638}}</ref> This is a condition where irregularities in the brain's [[limbic system]] may present as symptoms of [[paranoid schizophrenia]].<ref>{{cite journal | url = http://schizophreniabulletin.oxfordjournals.org/content/23/3/513.full.pdf | title = The Temporolimbic System Theory of Paranoid Schizophrenia | first = Manuel F. | last = Casanova | journal = [[Schizophrenia Bulletin]] | volume = 23 | number = 3 | year = 1997 | pages = 513–515 | publisher = Oxford University Press | doi=10.1093/schbul/23.3.513}}</ref>
In a 2010 study, Swiss psychiatrists found religious delusions with themes of spiritual persecution by malevolent spirit-entities, control exerted over the person by spirit-entities, delusional experience of sin and guilt, or [[Grandiose delusions|delusions of grandeur]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1521/psyc.2010.73.2.158 |title=Delusions with Religious Content in Patients with Psychosis: How They Interact with Spiritual Coping |year=2010 |last1=Mohr |first1=Sylvia |last2=Borras |first2=Laurence |last3=Betrisey |first3=Carine |last4=Pierre-Yves |first4=Brandt |last5=Gilliéron |first5=Christiane |last6=Huguelet |first6=Philippe |journal=Psychiatry: Interpersonal and Biological Processes |volume=73 |issue=2 |pages=158–172}}</ref>
Religious delusions have generally been found to be less stressful than [[Delusion#Themes|other types of delusion]].<ref name="raja2000" /> A study found adherents to [[new religious movement]]s to have similar delusionary cognition, as rated by the Delusions Inventory, to a psychotic group, although the former reported feeling less distressed by their experiences than the latter.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1348/014466599162683 |title=Delusional ideation in religious and psychotic populations |year=1999 |last1=Peters |first1=Emmanuelle |last2=Day |first2=Samantha |last3=McKenna |first3=Jacqueline |last4=Orbach |first4=Gilli |journal=British Journal of Clinical Psychology |volume=38 |pages=83–96 |pmid=10212739}}</ref>
==History== Behaviours out of the ordinary were traditionally viewed as [[demonic possession]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0500960.htm | archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20050222221921/http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0500960.htm | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2005-02-22 | year=2005 | work=Catholic News Service | accessdate=2012-01-23 | title=Real possession by devil not that common, exorcists say during lesson | last=Wooden | first=Cibndy }}</ref> These episodes, although entirely disavowed by modern psychiatry,<ref>{{cite book| last=Peck | first = M. Scott | title=Glimpses of the Devil: a psychiatrist's personal accounts of possession, exorcism, and redemption | publisher=Simon and Schuster | date=4 Jan 2005 | isbn=0-7432-5467-8}}</ref> are evaluated by clinicians only such that they fall within the safety of a treatment programme.
Earlier{{when|date=March 2015}} propositions that religious shamans were motivated by delusions and that their behaviour resembled that of patients with [[schizophrenia]] were found to be incorrect.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1525/ae.1983.10.3.02a00030 |title=Shamanism and schizophrenia: A state-specific approach to the 'schizophrenia metaphor' of shamanic states |year=1983 |last1=Noll |first1=Richard |journal=American Ethnologist |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=443–459}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pmid=12018978 |year=2002 |last1=Polimeni |first1=J |last2=Reiss |first2=JP |title=How shamanism and group selection may reveal the origins of schizophrenia |volume=58 |issue=3 |pages=244–8 |doi=10.1054/mehy.2001.1504 |journal=Medical Hypotheses}}</ref>
In a 1937 essay, [[Sigmund Freud]] stated that he considered believing in a [[single god]] to be a delusion,<ref name="Sims"/> thus extending his 1907 comment that religion is the indication of obsessional neurosis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freud.org.uk/education/topic/10573/subtopic/40000/ |title=Religion as obsessional neurosis |publisher=[[Freud Museum]] | last=Freud | first = Sigmund | year=1907}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1192/apt.10.4.287 |title=Working with patients with religious beliefs |year=2004 |last1=Dein |first1=S. |journal=Advances in Psychiatric Treatment |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=287–294}}</ref> His thoughts defining "delusion" perhaps crystallized from the notion of the religion formulations of the common man (''circa'' 1927) as "patently infantile, foreign to reality";<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freud.org.uk/education/topic/10573/subtopic/40005/ |title=Religion as a mass delusion |publisher=Freud Museum |last=Freud | first = Sigmund | year=1931}}</ref> around the same year he also stated that religion "comprises a system of wishful illusions together with a disavowal of reality, such as we find in an isolated form nowhere else but amentia, in a state of blissful hallucinatory confusion".<ref>{{cite book| title=The Future of an Illusion|last=Freud | first = Sigmund | year=1927 | isbn=978-0-393-00831-9 | oclc= 20479722}} cited in: {{cite journal |doi=10.1590/S0101-60832007000700013 |title=Religion, spirituality and psychotic disorders |year=2007 |last1=Koenig |first1=Harold G. |journal=Revista de Psiquiatria Clínica |volume=34 |pages=95–104}}</ref>
==Prevalence== Examples from a 295-subject study in [[Lithuania]] showed that the most common religious delusions were being a saint (in women) and being God (in men).<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=18695349 |year=2008 |last1=Rudaleviciene |first1=P |last2=Stompe |first2=T |last3=Narbekovas |first3=A |last4=Raskauskiene |first4=N |last5=Bunevicius |first5=R |title=Are religious delusions related to religiosity in schizophrenia? |volume=44 |issue=7 |pages=529–35 |journal=Medicina}}</ref>
In one study of 193 people who had previously been admitted to hospital and subsequently diagnosed with schizophrenia, 24% were found to have religious delusions.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s001270200005 |title=Religious delusions in patients admitted to hospital with schizophrenia |year=2002 |last1=Siddle |first1=Ronald |last2=Haddock |first2=Gillian |last3=Tarrier |first3=Nicholas |last4=Faragher |first4=E.Brian |journal=Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology |volume=37 |issue=3 |pages=130–8 |pmid=11990010}}</ref>
A 1999 study identified that religious delusions were often present or expressed in persons with [[Forensic psychiatry|forensic]] committal to a psychiatric unit.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1037/h0087835 |title=Understanding the religious ideation of forensically committed patients |year=1999 |last1=Kunst |first1=Jennifer L. |journal=Psychotherapy: Theory, Research, Practice, Training |volume=36 |issue=3 |pages=287–297 | url = http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/pst/36/3/287/}}</ref>
==Clinical examples==
===Biblical=== {{see also|Neuroscience of religion|Psychology of religion|Mental health of Jesus}} Although many researchers have brought evidence for a positive role that religion plays in health, others have shown that religious practices and experiences may be linked to [[mental illness]]es of various kind ([[mood disorders]], [[personality disorders]], [[psychiatric disorders]]). In 2011, a team of [[psychiatrists]], [[Behaviorism|behavioral psychologists]], [[neurologists]] and [[Neuropsychiatry|neuropsychiatrists]] from the [[Harvard Medical School]] published a research which suggested the development of a new diagnostic category of psychiatric disorders related to religious delusion and [[hyperreligiosity]].<ref name="JNCN">{{cite journal |last=Murray |first=Evan D. |last2=Cunningham |first2=Miles G. |last3=Price |first3=Bruce H. |title=The Role of Psychotic Disorders in Religious History Considered |journal=Journal of Neuropsichiatry and Clinical Neurosciences |publisher=[[American Psychiatric Association]] |volume=24 |issue=4 |date=September 2011 |pages=410–426 |doi=10.1176/appi.neuropsych.11090214 |cid= |url=https://neuro.psychiatryonline.org/doi/full/10.1176/appi.neuropsych.11090214 |access-date=March 22, 2018 |issn=1545-7222 }}</ref>
They compared the thought and behavior of the most important figures in the [[Bible]] ([[Abraham]], [[Moses]], [[Jesus Christ]] and [[Paul of Tarsus|Paul]])<ref name="JNCN" /> with patients affected by mental disorders related to the [[Spectrum disorder#Psychosis|psychotic spectrum]] using different clusters of disorders and diagnostic criteria ([[DSM-IV-TR]]),<ref name="JNCN" /> and concluded that these Biblical figures "may have had psychotic symptoms that contributed inspiration for their revelations",<ref name="JNCN" /> such as [[schizophrenia]], [[schizoaffective disorder]], [[Bipolar disorder|manic depression]], [[delusional disorder]], [[Grandiose delusions|delusions of grandeur]], [[Auditory hallucination|auditory]]-[[visual hallucination]]s, [[paranoia]], [[Geschwind syndrome]] (Paul especially) and abnormal experiences associated with [[temporal lobe epilepsy]] (TLE).<ref name="JNCN" />
In 1998–2000 [[Poles|Pole]] Leszek Nowak (born 1962)<ref>Not to be confused with Polish philosopher and lawyer [[Leszek Nowak]] (1943–2009) also from Poznań.</ref> from [[Poznań]] authored a study in which, based on his own history of religious delusions of mission and overvalued ideas, and information communicated in the Gospels, made an attempt at reconstructing Jesus′ psyche<ref>Leszek Nowak, [https://web.archive.org/web/20160514125307/http://www.opracowanie.eu/index_2.htm Prywatna Witryna Internetowa Leszka Nowaka] at [[Internet Archive]] (Polish)</ref> with the view of [[Portraits of the historical Jesus#Apocalyptic prophet|Jesus as apocalyptic prophet]].<ref name=Nowak>Analysis of fragments of the New Testament books for Jesus as apocalyptic prophet: Leszek Nowak, [https://web.archive.org/web/20160523101437/http://www.opracowanie.eu/pomylka_2.htm ″A great mistake and disappointment of early Christianity″] at [[Internet Archive]] (Polish)</ref> He does so in chapters containing, in sequence, an analysis of character traits of the ″savior of mankind″, a description of the possible course of events from the period of Jesus' public activity, a [[Naturalism (philosophy)|naturalistic]] explanation of miracles.
===Historical=== A religious experience of communication from heavenly or divine beings could be interpreted as a test of faith. An example of such is [[Joan of Arc]], ''La Pucelle d'Orléans'',<ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=A1NrfO2uFNAC | title = A Still, Small Voice: A Practical Guide on Reporting Revelations | first = Father Benedict J. | last = Groeschel | publisher = Ignatius Press | year = 1993 | pages = 52–53| isbn = 9780898704365 }}</ref> who rallied French forces late in the [[Hundred Years' War]].
[[Daniel Paul Schreber]] is an example of a supposed religious delusion occurring in a developed condition of psychosis.<ref>{{cite book | last=Corveleyn | first=Jozef | chapter=Religious Delusion in Psychosis and Hysteria | title=Changing the Scientific Study of Religion: Beyond Freud? | editor-first=J. A. |editor-last=Belzen | year=2009 | publisher=Springer | isbn=9789048125401}}</ref> Schreber was a successful and highly respected German judge until middle age, when he came to believe that God was turning him into a woman. Two of his three illnesses (1884–1885 and 1893–1902) are described in his book ''Memoirs of My Nervous Illness'' (original German title ''Denkwürdigkeiten eines Nervenkranken''),<ref>{{cite book | last =Schreber | first =Daniel Paul | title =Memoirs of My Nervous Illness | publisher =New York Review of Books, 2000 | year = 1903 | location =New York | isbn = 0-940322-20-X}}</ref> which became an influential book in the history of [[psychiatry]] and [[psychoanalysis]] thanks to its interpretation by [[Sigmund Freud]].<ref #Freud>{{cite book | last =Freud | first =Sigmund | authorlink =Sigmund Freud | last2 =Webber | first2 =Andrew (translator) | last3 =MacCabe | first3 =Colin (contributor) | authorlink3 =Colin MacCabe | title =The Schreber Case | publisher =Penguin Classics Psychology, 2003 | year = 1911 | location =New York | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=iY1917GJxqEC&pg=PR22&lpg=PR22&dq=isbn=0142437425#PPP1,M1 | isbn = 0-14-243742-5}}</ref>
The Harvard Medical School research also focused on [[Social psychology|social models]] of [[psychopathology]],<ref name="JNCN" /> analyzing [[new religious movements]] and charismatic [[Cult|cult leaders]] such as [[David Koresh]], leader of the [[Branch Davidians]],<ref name="JNCN" /> and [[Marshall Applewhite]], founder of the [[Heaven's Gate (religious group)|Heaven's Gate cult]].<ref name="JNCN" /> The researchers concluded that "If David Koresh and Marshall Applewhite are appreciated as having psychotic-spectrum beliefs, then the premise becomes untenable that the diagnosis of psychosis must rigidly rely upon an inability to maintain a social group. A subset of individuals with psychotic symptoms appears able to form intense social bonds and communities despite having an extremely distorted view of reality. The existence of a better socially functioning subset of individuals with psychotic-type symptoms is corroborated by research indicating that psychotic-like experiences, including both bizarre and non-bizarre delusion-like beliefs, are frequently found in the general population. This supports the idea that psychotic symptoms likely lie on a continuum."<ref name="JNCN" />
===Auditory hallucination and crime=== An individual may hear communication from heavenly or divine beings compelling one to [[religious violence|commit acts of violence]]. Some cite the case of the Hebrew patriarch [[Abraham]],<ref>{{cite journal | last=Katz | first=Claire Elise | title=The Voice of God and the Face of the Other: Levinas, Kierkegaard, and Abraham | journal=The Journal of Textual Reasoning | date=2001 | url=http://jtr.lib.virginia.edu/archive/volume10/Katz.html | volume=10 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225214716/http://jtr.lib.virginia.edu/archive/volume10/Katz.html | archivedate=2013-12-25 | df= }}</ref> who was commanded by God to [[Binding of Isaac|sacrifice his son Isaac]]. However, when Abraham was prepared to act on it, God informed him that this was only a test of faith and forbade any human sacrifice.
In contemporary times persons judged to have experienced [[auditory hallucination]] include those hearing voices instructing or motivating them to commit violent acts. These auditory experiences are classified by psychiatry as [[command hallucination]].<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=18477881 |year=2008 |last1=Shawyer |first1=F |last2=MacKinnon |first2=A |last3=Farhall |first3=J |last4=Sims |first4=E |last5=Blaney |first5=S |last6=Yardley |first6=P |last7=Daly |first7=M |last8=Mullen |first8=P |last9=Copolov |first9=D |title=Acting on harmful command hallucinations in psychotic disorders: An integrative approach |volume=196 |issue=5 |pages=390–8 |doi=10.1097/NMD.0b013e318171093b |journal=The Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease }}</ref> Persons acting to commit [[murder]] are reported as hearing voices of religious beings such as [[God]],<ref>{{cite news | last=Gaines | first = James | authorlink = James R. Gaines | date=March 9, 1987 | newspaper=[[The People]] | url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20095787,00.html | volume=27 | number=10 | title=Mark Chapman Part III: the Killer Takes His Fall}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | work=United Press International | title=Dad: God told me to kill my son | date=12 February 2009 | url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/02/12/Dad-God-told-me-to-kill-my-son/UPI-71281234475937/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://current.com/news-and-politics/89890038_man-says-he-killed-his-son-because-god-told-him-to.htm | title=Man says he killed his son because God told him to | date=March 15, 2009 | work=Current | archiveurl=https://archive.today/20120717043226/http://current.com/news-and-politics/89890038_man-says-he-killed-his-son-because-god-told-him-to.htm | archivedate=2012-07-17 | deadurl=yes | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title="Allah" Told Him to Kill His Family | first = Kim | last = Vatis | first2 = Jenel | last2 = Nels | date = April 14, 2010 | work=NBC Chicago | url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/Four-Shot-in-Marquette-Park-90819234.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Gamiz, Jr. | first=Manuel | title=Allentown slashing suspect says God commanded him to kill | newspaper=The Morning Call | date=30 November 2010 | url=http://articles.mcall.com/2010-11-30/news/mc-allentown-slashing-god-20101130_1_allentown-woman-lamp-cord-allentown-police}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Puxley | first=Chinta | title='God' told man to kill bus passenger | newspaper=Toronto Star | date=March 4, 2009 | url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2009/03/04/god_told_man_to_kill_bus_passenger.html | publisher=The Canadian Press | accessdate=2012-01-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Coryell | first=Lisa | title=New trial ordered for Morrisville man who says God told him to kill | newspaper=New Jersey Times | date=28 February 2011 | url=http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2011/02/new_trial_ordered_for_morrisvi.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Spoto | first=Maryann | title=Man Who Says God Told Him to Kill Girlfriend Gets New Trial | work=Ethics Daily | url=http://ethicsdaily.com/man-who-says-god-told-him-to-kill-girlfriend-gets-new-trial-cms-17538 | date = March 3, 2011}}</ref> [[angels]],<ref>{{cite news | last=Petrie | first=Andrea | newspaper=The Age | title=Schizophrenic stabbed grandmother to death 'after hearing voice of angel' | accessdate=22 January 2012 | date=22 July 2010 | url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/schizophrenic-stabbed-grandmother-to-death-after-hearing-voice-of-angel-20100722-10mco.html}}</ref> or the [[Devil]].<ref>{{cite web | last=LaCapria | first=K. | work=The Inquisitr News | title=Horrific: Mother kills, eats baby in Texas | accessdate=23 January 2012 | url=http://www.inquisitr.com/30950/horrific-mother-kills-eats-baby-in-texas/ | date=28 July 2009}}</ref>
Within the [[anti-psychiatry]] community, Professor Thomas Szasz critiques the concept of religious auditory hallucination: those who hear the voice of God talking to them are experiencing schizophrenia, while those who talk to God but hear no response are simply [[Prayer|praying]].<ref>{{cite web | work=Citizens Commission on Human Rights International | title=Professor Thomas Szasz on Schizophrenia as a Disease | accessdate=23 January 2012 | url=http://www.cchrint.org/about-us/co-founder-dr-thomas-szasz/quotes-on-schizophrenia-as-a-disease/}}</ref>

{{use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{use Indian English|date=March 2016}} {{more footnotes|date=March 2016}} [[File:Bahubali Shravana Belagola.jpg|thumb|200px|upright|The Lord [[Bahubali]] statue symbolising absolute renunciation from the [[Samsara]].]] '''Renunciation''' (or '''renouncing''') is the act of rejecting something, especially if it is something that the renouncer has previously enjoyed or endorsed.
In religion, renunciation often indicates an abandonment of pursuit of material comforts, in the interests of achieving [[spiritual enlightenment]]. It is highly practiced in Jainism. In [[Hinduism]], the renounced order of life is ''[[sannyasa|sannyāsa]]''; in Buddhism, the Pali word for "renunciation" is ''[[nekkhamma]]'', conveying more specifically "giving up the world and leading a holy life" or "freedom from lust, craving and desires".<ref>Rhys Davids & Stede (1921-25), p. 377, [http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.2:1:692.pali entry for "Nekkhamma"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120707141638/http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.2:1:692.pali |date=7 July 2012 }} (retrieved 2008-04-12). Rhys Davids & Stede speculate that the [[Sanskrit]] term with which ''nekkhamma'' is associated is either: :* ''nai{{IAST|ṣ}}kramya'' — "inactivity, abstinence or exemption from acts and their consequences" ([http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/cgi-bin/serveimg.pl?file=/scans/MWScan/MWScanjpg/mw0570-naipAtya.jpg Monier Williams, 1964, p. 570, entry for "Naish"]) :* ''nai{{IAST|ṣ}}kāmya'' — "suppression of desire, profound contemplation" ([http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/cgi-bin/serveimg.pl?file=/scans/MWScan/MWScanjpg/mw0570-naipAtya.jpg ''ibid''.]).</ref> See [[Sangha]], [[Bhikkhu]], [[Bhikkhuni]], [[Śramaṇa]]. In [[Christianity]], some denominations have a tradition of renunciation of [[the Devil]].
Legally, renunciation arises in [[nationality law]] with the [[renunciation of citizenship]], a formal process by which the renouncer ceases to hold [[citizenship]] with a specific country. A person can also renounce property, as when a person submits a [[disclaimer of interest]] in property that has been left to them in a [[will (law)|will]].
==Mahatma Gandhi==
It is widely believed in India that voluntary renunciation is how one gains power, for whatever purpose. In South Africa (1893-1915) [[Gandhi]] tried many spiritual practices and experiments, almost all of them including a component of renunciation, based in the practice of [[Sannyasi]]. After reading “Unto this Last” By John Ruskin in 1904 he redoubled his commitment to gain greater control over self, increasing his capacity to work for the common welfare and find a greater sense of oneness with others. The ultimate renunciation is of self, one's separateness from others and the world.
==Christianity== In some [[Christianity|Christian]] [[Christian denomination|denominations]], renunciation of the [[Devil in Christianity|Devil]] is a common [[Liturgy|liturgical]] [[rubric]]. This is most often seen in connection with the sacrament of [[baptism]]. In the [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] church a baptism usually contains the "Prayer of Exorcism". Later in the ceremony, the parents and [[Godparent|godparents]] are asked to publicly renounce the devil.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.catholicliturgy.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/textcontents/index/4/subindex/67/textindex/7|title=The Catholic Liturgical Library|website=www.catholicliturgy.com|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref>
The [[Church of England]] dismissed this rubric in a 2014 renewal of liturgy. According to [[The Independent]], this was done in an attempt to "widen the appeal" of the rite.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/devil-vows-taken-out-of-christening-services-as-church-of-england-aims-to-widen-appeal-9604399.html|title=Devil vows taken out of Christening services as Church of England aims|date=2014-07-14|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-GB}}</ref> A prior report for the Church's Liturgical Commission stated that "[f]or the majority of those attending, the existing provision can seem complex and inaccessible."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-2690262/BAPTISM-SERVICES-MAY-OMIT-DEVIL.html|title=BAPTISM SERVICES MAY OMIT 'DEVIL'|work=Mail Online|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref>
In the [[Church of Norway]], the public renunciation of the Devil is a obligatory element in the [[Church service|Main Service]]. It is stated by the congregation before the profession of faith (usually the [[Apostles' Creed]], as the [[Nicene Creed]] is largely reserved for special observances). When performed in a service which includes a baptism, it is also considered an extension of the testimony given by the [[Godparent|sponsors]], as they are required to confess to a denomination which does not rejects the Apostles' or the Nicene Creed, nor rejects [[infant baptism]].<ref>https://kirken.no/globalassets/kirken.no/om-troen/liturgier-oversatt/the-order-of-the-principal-service.pdf "''The Order of the Principal Service''", as derived from "''The Service Book for the Church of Norway''". Authorized by the General Synod in 2011. Valid from 3.12.11 and obligatory from 1.12.12</ref><ref>https://kirken.no/globalassets/kirken.no/om-troen/liturgier-oversatt/baptism_independent_service.pdf "The order of Baptism as an independent service" as derived from "''The Service Book for the Church of Norway''". Authorized by the General Synod in 2011. Valid from 3.12.11 and obligatory from 1.12.12</ref><ref>https://kirken.no/globalassets/kirken.no/om-troen/gudstjeneste---liturgi/gudst2011_2012_alm_bestemmelser_daap_bokm.pdf "''Allmenne bestemmelser for dåp"'' [General provisions for baptism]. Authorized by the General Synod in 2011. Applies from 3.12.11 and supreme from 1.12.12</ref>
